Dear Mrs. Fernandez:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
 How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
 Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 For repeat violations, identify why the previous plan was unsuccessful.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please note that violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the MISEP and
your contract.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the local office at (866) 685-0006.

ALLEGATION:
There have been inappropriate sexual behaviors and aggression between two youth
at the facility and staff continued to allow them to reside in the same cottage. The
facility was aware of one of the youth's inappropriate sexual behavior upon being
admitted into the facility. While youth were recently separated, they can still have
access if there is inadequate supervision.
INVESTIGATION:
This complaint was transferred for investigation on 10/25/21,
Youth A (9) is a permanent ward placed at Methodist Children's Home Society.
Youth A and Youth B (last name unknown) both resided in the same cottage
together. There were inappropriate sexualized behaviors that occurred between
the two and the facility continued to allow them to reside in the same cottage.
There were numerous incident reports for physical aggression between the two.
The recent incident of sexualized behavior between the two was due to improper
supervision. Youth A was giving oral sex to Youth B. Methodist Children's Home
Society was informed of Youth A’s history of inappropriate sexual behavior upon
him moving into the facility. The facility has reported that they have moved the
child, Youth B, to a different cottage, but the children could have access to each
other if there is not adequate supervision.
During a PCU conference call on 10/25/21, Youth A’s worker, Youth B’s worker, and
the PCU staff reported that this incident of sexual acting out had been previously
reported and dismissed, however, additional information was learned, and they
wanted to rereport it. I followed up via email with the complainant on 10/25/21. The
complainant reported that to their knowledge, there was an investigation of this
3

incident, which occurred 10/01/21. The complainant said that the youth were allowed
to go into another room while the staff and other youth watched a movie in a
different room. The complainant reported the person to contact regarding the
investigation was the PCU staff. In following up with the PCU staff via email, the
PCU staff said that the information they had was directly from the foster care
workers for Youth A and Youth B and they didn’t have anything additional.
MiSACWIS information was reviewed for the original incident (ID 85686544), and it
was found that this incident was previously reported on the same day of the incident,
10/01/21, by the facility. The report noted the following.
In the afternoon hours of 10/1/21 Youth A performed oral sex on Youth B. This
incident took place in the living room area of the home. This occurred randomly
out the blue and very quickly. Staff was present in the room and immediately
intervened and notified supervision of the incident. The two have since been
separated and have both been sent out to the ER for further evaluation. The
home is following appropriate steps moving forward for notification of necessary
and responsible parties and a safety plan will be devised to ensure both children
are separated and kept safe. The home does not have video surveillance for
review of the matter.
An incident of physical aggression between these two youth and staff supervision
was investigated by DCWL in SIR 2021C0108040 and no violations were found for
improper supervision. Email follow-up with the investigating DCWL Consultant found
that the facility did not promise to keep the two youths separated after this incident
but had temporarily separated them.
On 11/08/21, Youth A’s FCW reported the following via email. The FCW had visited
Youth A at the facility on 11/03/21 and arrived when Youth A was getting off the bus.
The FCW walked Youth A back to the cottages from the bus stop. Youth A reported
typically having four staff during the day and one at night in his cottage and
confirmed the safety plan is being followed. The FCW said that they addressed with
a cottage staff that there was no one at the bus stop to get Youth A and the staff
said the regular staff member that picks Youth A up from the bus stop was sick that
day and the designated substitute was late. On 11/10/21, the FCW confirmed that
the safety plan is for direct line of sight supervision for Youth A.
I met with the Director of Residential Services (DRS), on 10/27/21, at the facility. The
DRS said that she had reviewed this incident and it was being internally
investigated. Youth B has been moved to another cottage and there is a safety plan
in place for each youth. The DRS said that supervisors came in the following
weekend to check on staff, provide additional monitoring, and ensure that the
youth’s safety plans were being followed.
I interviewed Youth A at the facility, on 10/27/21. Youth A reported that he recalled
an incident on 10/01/21. Youth A said that he knows Youth B but doesn’t like him.
Youth A recalled Youth B being at the cottage as well as Staff 1. Youth A said that
he was watching television with his peers when he went to his bedroom to get a toy.
4

Youth A said that Youth B came and grabbed his toy and ran off with it, so Youth A
chased Youth B. Youth A said that Youth A pulled his pants down and showed
Youth A his “privates.” This reportedly occurred in the corner of the smaller living
room/playroom. Youth A said that Youth B tried to get him to “do other stuff and I
did.” Youth A did not provide further detail but did say he did not remember if he
touched Youth B’s “privates.” Youth A said he was only in his bedroom a couple of
seconds when retrieving the toy and was only in the back living room with Youth B
for a couple of minutes total. Youth A said that Staff 1 was in the kitchen when this
occurred. Youth A said this incident happened quickly and when Staff 1 saw them
she told Youth A to go to the other room. It was at this time that Youth A walked out
of the cottage.
I interviewed Youth B at the facility, on 10/27/21, but he was not open with
information. Youth B reported that he is now in Harrison cottage but was in Cotcher.
Youth B recalled an incident on 10/01/21 and said that he was asleep in the
playroom in the corner. Youth B said that when he fell asleep, he was alone in the
room and Youth A was not there. Youth B said that he also woke up alone and then
went back to the living room to watch television with the rest of the group. Youth B
said that Staff 1 was moving between the kitchen area and the back by the
bedrooms when he fell asleep. When he woke up, Youth B said that Staff 1 was in
the kitchen area, which is between the two rooms where the youth were.
I interviewed Staff 1 at the facility, on 10/27/21. Staff 1 reported that she was
working in the cottage on the morning of the incident, on 10/01/21, and stated that
she was supervising five youth. It was noted that she had four, but Youth A returned
from school unexpectedly. Staff 1 said that she had all of the youth in the front room
watching television when Youth B asked if he could go to the back room to separate
himself and think. Staff 1 allowed this and noted she monitored him by walking the
hall between the front living room and back room. Staff 1 said that Youth A “hopped
up” and went to his bedroom and dropped his shoes by his door. Youth A then
walked around the back hall and into the back living room where Youth B was. Staff
1 said that Youth A sat down, and Staff 1 prompted him to go back to the front room
to watch television with the other youth. Youth A refused. Staff 1 said that she was
not going to verbally escalate the situation and wasn’t going to physically move
Youth A, so she just went on to monitor both rooms by walking back and forth
continuously. Staff 1 said that she would walk through the kitchen, which separates
the two rooms, and by walking around the back hall by the bedrooms. Staff 1 said
she only took a few seconds between checks of each room since they are so close
to one another. On the third check of Youth A and Youth B in the back room, Staff 1
said that she saw Youth A bent over with his “butt” up and his face down near Youth
B’s private area. Staff 1 said that she didn’t see any skin or Youth B’s penis. Staff 1
said that she told Youth A to stop, and Youth A hopped up and walked out of the
cottage. Staff 1 said that neither youth has said what happened that day.
5

Documentation reviewed as part of this investigation:
 Internal investigation dated 11/08/21. The report provided an account by Staff
1 consistent with her interview. However, the report noted that Staff 1 initially
told an administrator that she was in the kitchen cooking when the incident
occurred, which was in contrast to the rest of the report and her interview.
The report noted that Staff 1 said she and another staff had nine youth that
morning. The report also noted up to five youth with Staff 1 at the cottage at
times during that morning. The report had mixed conclusions noting Human
Resources “determined that Staff 1 demonstrated that she did not have
appropriate knowledge of the children’s whereabouts,” and the Director of
Children’s Services “did not determine that Staff 1 demonstrated having a
lack of appropriate knowledge of the children’s whereabouts.”
 Internal Incident Report, dated 10/01/2021, authored by Staff 1. The incident
report was consistent with Staff 1’s interview.
 Safety plan for Youth A, dated 10/01/2021. Among other things, the plan
noted direct line of sight and no contact with Youth B.
 Safety plan for Youth B, dated 10/01/2021. Among other things, the plan
noted direct line of sight and no contact with Youth A.
 Supervisor Safety Plan, dated 10/01/2021, authored by DRS. Directed
supervisors to review the youth’s safety plans and ensure they are followed.
Additional staffing supports for the weekend were established as well.
6

APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4126 Sufficiency of staff.
The licensee shall have a sufficient number of
administrative, supervisory, social service, direct care, and
other staff on duty to perform the prescribed functions
required by these administrative rules and in the agency's
program statement and to provide for the continual needs,
protection, and supervision of residents.
ANALYSIS: The staff was providing active supervision. The staff did not
allow the youth to be together and tried to get Youth A to leave
the area, but Youth A refused, so Staff 1 continued to monitor
the youth in the two rooms, which were observed not to be far
apart (and of an open concept floorplan, although not
completely open). It appears that Youth A and Youth B were
able to manipulate the small window of opportunity in this
instance to act out sexually. This was noted by the staff and
stopped immediately.
While there is no violation related to allegations, there is a
violation of this rule, as Youth A has an established safety plan
that includes direct line of sight supervision, but the facility did
not ensure a staff was present to monitor him from the bus on
the day of the FCW visit.
CONCLUSION: REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
SIR 2022C0108003, intake 10/11/21, CAP approved 11/16/21
SIR 2020C0108009, intake 11/26/19, CAP approved 01/13/20
ADDITIONAL FINDINGS:
During the course of this investigation, it was found that the facility was out of ratio
on the morning of this incident, 10/01/2021.
7

APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4127 Staff-to-resident ratio.
(1) The licensee shall develop and adhere to a written staff-
to-resident ratio formula for direct care workers.
ANALYSIS: The facility is in violation of the rule as Staff 1 reported to be
alone with five youth on the day of this incident. This is
supported by the internal investigation notes which additionally
noted that there were two staff with nine residents the morning
of this incident when the facility ratio is one staff per four
residents.
CONCLUSION: REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
SIR 2021C0207024, intake 07/20/21, CAP approved 09/22/21
SIR 2021C0108045, intake 07/13/21, CAP approved 08/25/21
(cited as a contract violation for ratio)
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on the findings of this investigation, I recommend no change to the current
license status. This recommendation is contingent on the facility submitting an
acceptable corrective action plan for the noted violations.

sir_summary.summary: An investigation substantiated that two youths engaged in inappropriate sexual behavior due to a brief lapse in supervision while staff monitored two rooms. The facility failed to prevent this despite being aware of one youth's history and also violated staffing ratios on the day of the incident. While the report notes the youths 'manipulated' an opportunity, the facility bears clear responsibility for repeat violations of supervision and staffing rules.
